question: What kind of a crash was it?
There's nothing on the news about a crash. Did he say what airline?
answer: He didn't say much at all. Honey --

question: In the closet. I don't understand, Norman -- why would they call you?
Well, I can't imagine five years of unemployment --
Four years of unemployment would look too good on a resume.
answer: Keep watching the news. Are you watching the news?

question: How are you getting to the airport? You need money for the bus? There's a U.S. Navy car outside, Norman.
Was it a military crash?
What kinda work you in, Dr. Johnson?
answer: I'm in psychology. Was. Still am really, just been a while. I treat aircrash survivors.

question: Oh, so you're that Dr. Johnson.
Well, everybody's been talking about that report you wrote.
Huh?
You mean you don't know?
Must be another Johnson then. Been flying so many scientists out here -- can't keep everyone straight.
Physicists, mathematicians, geologists, you name it.
Strange, isn't it? In the middle of the ocean no less.
answer: What the hell would a geologist be doing at a plane crash?

question: What the hell would a geologist be doing at a plane crash?
Just that. Careful, it's heavy.
No, they didn't say --
answer: This way, sir. Captain Barnes wants to see you right away, sir.

question: Captain who?
answer: Barnes. He's very eager to meet you. Been calling us every half hour to see if you're arrived.

question: Really?
answer: By the way sir, I've read your report. I think it's brilliant.

question: What report?
answer: You mean they haven't told you yet?

question: Told me what?
How's he look?... Well, we can't all be officers, can we? They tell me he's brilliant. Dr. Norman Johnson. Welcome aboard.
Captain.
answer: Captain. Right, forgive me. Well, thanks for the opportuninty here -- my wife appreciates it.

question: Don't thank me, Dr. Johnson. You weren't my choice. The Pentagon made me take you.
answer: The Pentagon? I didn't know I had friends in Washington.

question: Come with me. The team's already waiting.
What have you been told so far?
answer: The usual. Plane crash. Survivers unknown. Routine stuff really.

question: Anything else?
You talk to any reporters? Any press?
Good. Security's been our biggest worry. Now that you're here we can shut this thing down tight.
answer: From what? What's with all the security?

question: Well, we don't have all the facts yet. We're moving fast considering the storm.
A cyclone's on it's way in. I thought they would have told you on the phone.
We've had divers working around the clock. Take a look at this...
A thousand feet.
answer: A thousand? An airplane crashes into a thousand feet of water -- I don't want to sound pessimistic here, but I assume there are no survivors.

question: Survivors? No, I wouldn't think so.
What?
answer: What do you need me for?

question: What crashed wasn't an airplane, Dr. Johnson. It's a bit larger than that. Bring up the grid, would you?
answer: What is it? A military spacecraft? Like a shuttle or satellite?

question: Something like that. That doesn't surprise you?
answer: Not really, no. Something of the military crashes in the ocean -- it explains why there was nothing on the news, why you've kept everything a secret... When did it crash?

question: As best we can estimate, it crashed four hundred years ago.
See this? Coral. Geologists measured the coral growth on top of the craft to be over five meters thick.
Coral grows at a rate of two and a half centimeters a year --
-- dating the crash at least that old.
Maybe older --
answer: -- there's got to be some mistake here -- a four hundred year old military spacecraft? There's no such thing... our space program isn't even forty years old.

question: Extraordinary, isn't it?
I'm afraid it is Dr. Johnson... because it's sitting on the bottom of our ocean floor. Off the record, I don't mind telling you, this thing scares the shit out of me.
We think it might. That's why we brought you here. We've assembled your team -- they're waiting for us now.
The one you recommended. In the ULF report you wrote for the Bush administration.
answer: ULF report? Nobody's mentioned that in years. You mean someone actually read it?

question: Your report's become our bible down here, Dr. Johnson. We've been carrying out each of your recommendations -- one by one -- to the smallest detail.
answer: But sir, I don't understand. This report -- these recommendations... they're for an encounter with extra- terrestrial life.

question: The wing dimension alone is larger that any aircraft we've seen.
To the craft? None. Not a scratch.
answer: Right. So you're saying it survived a high speed impact with water without a scratch?

question: Five years. No phone calls. What am I -- a leper?
answer: Beth, look, can I trust you with a little secret?

question: I love secrets.
answer: That ULF report everybody's patting me on the back about?

question: I've read it twice, Norman. It's brilliant.
answer: It's bullshit. The report's a joke.

question: That's quite a secret.
answer: I spent a week reading Sagan and watching re-runs of the Twilight Zone. Seriously. I was just trying to pay the mortgage on my house -- I had no idea --

question: Do yourself a favor, Norman. Are you listening? Don't tell anyone what you just told me.
answer: C'mon, Beth -- that report's like the blind leading the blind.

question: Because when we get down there --
To the spacecraft. To investigate.
What do you expect? For them to bring it up here?
answer: We can't go down there. We're not prepared. That deep? That takes years of training, Beth. We're just scientists. Lab scietists. We wear ties and lab coats to work -- not oxygen tanks.

question: Well, you must have realized the chances an encounter like this would happen here. In the ocean. 70 percent of the earth's surface is water, Norman. That's first grade geography.
Well, let's pray that's the only mistake you made. Have you said anything to Barnes about this?
answer: The timing has never seemed quite right.

question: Just keep your mouth shut, alright? This could mean everything to our careers, you know that? Don't jeopardize this.
What -- are you threatening me?
answer: I don't know you, but I'll be honest with you. I don't like this. I don't like any of this. Especially, the water.

question: Seasick? A marine biologist?
answer: I don't belong here. None of us belong here. Look at that.

question: Makes you feel pretty small, doesn't it?
answer: It scares the shit out of me.

question: Open the hatch door, please. Captain, open the hatch door, please ... the hatch door, Captain. Open it, please.
Let me out, Captain. Open the door!
answer: Please, Dr. Levine. Sit down, Dr. Levine! You're in a military operation now -- ... Your civil rights have been overridden!

question: Open it, Captain!
answer: Dr. Levine, please! Return to your seat!

question: Open the fucking door!
How are you feeling, Norman?
You holding up alright?
Don't be defensive.
You sound defensive.
What'd you say to him?
answer: To who? Arthur? Nothing. Nothing that Norman doesn't already know.

question: What does Norman already know?
answer: Norman thinks we shouldn't be going down. Thinks it's a mistake. She told me what you said, Norman.

question: What is it, Harry?
answer: Just one of Norman's many secrets.

question: Duly noted, Ted. Edmunds, try using suction.
Thank you, I can see that. Try something else.
answer: We don't have anything else to try, Sir.

question: Isn't there a psychological term for that, Dr. Johnson?
You're next, Norman.
answer: No. Go ahead. Really. Ladies first.

question: Go ahead. Ladies first.
C'mon.
answer: Wait a second, I -- Geez, c'mon, alright. Gimme a minute. Let me get my bearings --

question: C'mon, Norman.
It's chipped.
answer: Chipped? The door? How can it be chipped?

question: I don't know how it can be chipped, but it's chipped.
answer: I thought you said there wasn't any damage done in the crash?

question: I did.
answer: Then how can it be chipped?

question: There's heat coming the door.
Wait a minute --
Would you wait a minute?
answer: Ted, get her away from the door.

question: Look at this.
Some sort of lead or something.
It doesn't make any sense.
answer: You don't think it does? I think it's rather obvious.

question: Is it some sort of joke? Like one of those hoaxes?
answer: A spacecraft half a mile long -- with 500 tonnes of coral on top of it? Someone went to a lot of trouble. Try again.

question: But it's impossible.
Why would this ship carry instructions in English?
All the facts you need are right in front of you.
answer: Gimme a minute here... I think I've got it.

question: Do you?
answer: If it is an alien spacecraft --

question: Considered what? That it's American? How would you think it's American?
answer: The chip in the door. We take a weeny little wedge, bang on it a couple of times, and bust off a chunk of the metal. Yet any spacecraft -- even at a low velocity, say 200 miles an hour -- crashes into the water -- it's gonna be like hitting concrete, it would crumple like paper. But there isn't a dent to be seen anywhere. Not even a scratch.

question: Meaning?
answer: Meaning it didn't land in the water.

question: Please. It must have flown here --
answer: It didn't fly here. It arrived here.

question: Arrived? From where?
answer: Not where. When. 400 years ago. From our future.

question: What's that noise?
Norman!
Nice work, Norman.
answer: Whatever I can do to help.

question: A flight recorder. Our future is about to be seen in our present.
answer: 01-01-47. Two thousand-forty seven. 50 years in our future.

question: This answers one of our questions.
answer: Which one? Let me get the list out.

question: This spacecraft was designed to pick things up. They see things they want -- these claws go out and bring it in. They come across this. This... sphere. Find it interesting, curious. They draw it inside to take back home.
answer: But on the way home, they miss their turn, go too far, into the past.

question: Like "Thou shall not kill"?
answer: Or maybe, it can't be killed.

question: You mean, what's in that thing is immortal?
answer: I don't know. That's the point.

question: Or it could contain some great benefit to us, some astonishing new idea or technology to help mankind.
answer: It could. But the odds of it being any use to us are against it.

question: You don't know that.
answer: Let's say whoever made this thing is a thousand years ahead of us, just like we are to, say, medieval Europe. Suppose you went back to medieval Europe with a TV set. There wouldn't be any place to plug it in.

question: You realize, Norman, that we are all going to die.
I'm completely serious. There is something very important missing from that spacecraft. You know what that is?
A sign that the builders knew time travel through a black hole was possible.

On that flight recorder, they called the black hole an "Unknown Entry Event." They didn't know what a black hole was. Fifty years from now, men are going to build that ship in a very tentative, experimental way, with no knowledge that time travel through a black hole is possible.

So, we know. We know it went through a black hole. We saw it. Norman -- when we'd get to the surface, we'd tell someone about the black hole, wouldn't we? It'd go in some report like some big discovery. So in fifty years when they build that ship, they'd make precautions for a black hole. But they didn't. The called it an Unknown Entry Event.
answer: Meaning we're never gonna get the chance to tell anyone.

question: Meaning we're never gonna get to the surface alive... to tell anyone.
Gimme another explanation.
answer: I can't. If I had a minute to think, maybe, but I know you're wrong.

question: Am I?
answer: Look -- we're under a lot of pressure, we're tired, you're not thinking straight.

question: You mean, you think I'm cracking?
Then what, Norman?
answer: It's what's in that sphere, isn't it, Harry? Whatever you think is in that thing -- you think it's going to kill you.

question: Don't get hysterical, Norman.
answer: I'm telling you, Harry's lost it. He's saying there's a deathwish out for each of us.

question: Look, the ships are clearing out. They're taking us topside in a matter of minutes. Someone can check him out there, if it's that imprtant.
answer: All I'm saying is, someone should keep an eye on him.

question: Ted, shut up. Are you packed? Ready to go? I want everyone packed. Now!
What do you mean, he's missing?
answer: He's missing. He's gone. He left.

question: Gimme a report, I want --
Who is that? Where's that coming from?
Send them, damn it! I know, but I'm not gonna be held responsible --
answer: You can't just leave Harry down here, sir.

question: I told you people, nobody goes anywhere unless I say.
Edmunds, do you have a 20 on Norman?
Well, where the fuck is he?
You get your ass back here. You have no authority whatsoever to be in there. You hear me?... Norman? Don't go hero on me now.
answer: Sir, if the subs haven't left by now...

question: They've left, keep watching!
answer: Sir! Sir, the door -- it's opening.

question: What is that? That noise?
It's like...
answer: Harry, can you tell me about the sphere?

question: What are you still doing here?
You were all supposed to leave. You weren't supposed to stay down here.
answer: Tell me about the door. Do you remember how you opened the door to the sphere?... Harry?

question: You don't understand about the sphere.
Norman?
What happens on page 87? Have you ever read page 87?
I could never read that far. I never wanted to.
Beth -- I wanted to have a word with you... Back at the door -- I asked you to back away.
There are procedures, Beth, that I want followed. My procedures. And considering what's going on, I want you to follow them very closely.
answer: Forgive me. I've never read the Navy manual. I wonder what it says about bathroom and shower procedures.

question: When did it come across?
answer: Minutes ago. Harry's trying to decode it in his room now.

question: Where's it coming from?
answer: No idea. We have no surface support. It transmitted too fast to be coming from underwater.

question: Is it coming from our own computer?
answer: Harry thinks it's some sort of discharge from our own system, but I've seen it discharge before -- and it didn't look anything like this.

question: Getting anywhere with those?
answer: There's some sort of pattern here. It'll take a minute.

question: Have you looked outside? Jellyfish. Everywhere. I hate jellyfish. Harry, what happened in the cafeteria?
answer: Don't do this. Don't psychoanalyze me. I hate squid. Period. Just like you hate jellyfish.

question: You said something to me, before -- about how we were all going to die.
You don't remember that?
answer: I don't remember much. It's like my memory is on the tip of my tongue -- but I can't taste any of it. Funny, my senses are much keener though. Purer. Hearing, seeing, smelling. Like, I can smell your sheets, Norman. You tried to wash it out earlier, But I can still smell the urine. Don't worry, I'm not going to tell the others. It's normal, really, isn't it? In a crisis. The stress. The panic.

question: I can't see, they're smearing the faceplate. My arms... the fabric...
It's burning...
I can't see...
I can't...
What is this, Beth? You taking valium?
answer: Sedatives. Whatever my mood calls for.

question: Where'd this come from?
We have a library?
answer: A bad one. It was the only book in there. Norman, come here, look at this.

question: No, thank you. I hate jellyfish. ... when I was six, my younger brother and I -- we went swimming in the Pacific. At my mother's beach house. We both felt stinging, and when we came out of the water, he was wearing jellyfish head to toe. Killed him.
Yeah, it was awful.
answer: What about you? What happened to you?

question: Me? Well, I was wrapped in seaweed. It itched for a while, but I survived. Beth, do you find it... curious that we're seeing all this life down here. Nothing, and then these enormous flocks of squid. Then jellyfish?
answer: Normally, I'd say no. Everything's quiet now -- no ships, no divers, no electricity. Makes sense. But what's curious is -- these aren't normal jellyfish.

question: What do you mean -- not normal?
answer: They have six tentacles. A new species. And the squid too. They had no stomach.

question: Wait a minute.
You knew about the squid not being normal. Before Fletcher went out there?
And you didn't tell anyone?
Beth --
answer: I mean, I'm not... I wasn't absolutely sure if... they --

question: They are or they aren't. Which is it?
answer: What?... Wait. Don't... why are you --

question: Beth.
answer: Nobody said... Norman... What? Why are you looking at me like that?

question: Beth --
answer: I didn't do anything wrong. I didn't mean...

question: Beth.
answer: You wouldn't go and tell the others, would you? I hate this place, Norman. I want out.

question: I'm not paranoid. I know Beth. She can be drastic.
You don't want to know.

A while back, Beth and I -- we worked at the same university. She was assisting a chemist there -- I forget his name -- doing research, experiments. She was also living with him. Yeah, I know. And when she finished her work, he kicked her out, broke off the relationship, and published five papers -- all her work -- without any thank you or acknowledgement.
She put a razor to her wrists a day later.
'81, I think. She tried again five years ago. I thought you should know.
answer: So you knew this when you wrote your report?

question: At the time, I don't know, I thought putting her on the list -- it might help her career -- catch her a break.
answer: You knowingly recommended a woman with suicidal tendencies for a government operation --

question: Wait a second --
answer: -- and then brought her down here --

question: -- I didn't know it would come to this --
answer: -- without a cautionary word to anyone. You know, Ted said something to me earlier. I think he's right. He said, "When you got a guy who -- if he wasn't here -- he'd be standing in the unemployment line, you gotta question if you got the right guy."

question: He's manic, Norman. You know that? This reliance on Harry is misplaced. You hear me? Totally misplaced. He's overlooking things. Obvious things.
It's not some fucking substitution code, it's a direct visual representation.
Take a look. I rearranged the numbers. Put 'em up to the light. Go ahead. Squint at it.
Squint harder.
Try this one.
Don't you see it? It's a picture of the creature.
Inside the sphere. Look, that's the vertical torso, three legs, two arms. There's no head, so I'm guessing the creature's head is located within the torso itself, you know?
answer: Well, how about we wait and see what Harry comes up with?

question: ... spiralling out of the center, you see
I have to tell you. It's strange.
"Hello. How are you? I am fine. What is your name? My name is Jerry."
answer: He translated it wrong. "My name is Jerry"? It's like "See Spot run."

question: When he uses a phrase like "I am Happy", I think we should think twice about what we ask him. Jerry, can you understand what we're saying? Jerry, can you read our minds?
answer: Edmunds, I want you in here. Now.

question: Jerry, are you there?
answer: We shouldn't talk here. Shut it off.

question: We would like to talk alone. And we enjoy talking with you. We'd like to talk with you more. We admire your talents and your great power and understanding. And in your great understanding, you know that we are entities who must talk in private -- with each other. We're not afraid, we are uncomfortable. Not at all, we enjoy you very much, but we need to talk alone, without you listening. Thank you. Jerry?... Jerry? Are you still there? Jerry?
answer: Edmunds? Get in here. I want to know exactly how this is being transmitted.

question: Edmunds?
answer: Because if Jerry is powerful and also emotional...

question: Damn it, Edmunds?
answer: ... it raises a very serious question

question: What is that?
answer: The sensors are picking up something outside.

question: What?
answer: It won't register. It's too big to image.

question: Well, until we know exactly what it is, nobody goes outside, understood?
Resetting the sub.
In the dome hanger. All our tapes are transferred to the sub. It's on a 12 hour timer. If someone doesn't reset the "delay" button, the sub ascends to the surface with the tapes.
If something should happen to us, the Navy will at least have partial records of what happened.
answer: At least our obituaries will be accurate. That's reassuring.

question: ... He lied to us. He left us down here.
answer: C'mon, Beth. Don't make this personal. He told me himself they were taking us back.

question: Yeah, he told you. Think. What was Barnes doing before they cut that cable loose? He was on the phone. Except that cable is a thousand feet long, Norman. They would've broken off communication with us four, five minutes before they cleared out.
So who was Barnes talking to at the last minute? Nobody.
answer: You're jumping to conclusions, Beth. Don't get worked up --

question: Fuck you, Norman! It's right here... "Although advised of risks, all personnel elect to remain down for duration of storm to continue investigation of alien sphere and associated spacecraft. Signed, Barnes, USN."
In Edmunds' things.
He's not just a Navy captain -- he works for the fucking Pentagon.
Don't tell me to calm down!
answer: It's done, alright? It's over! And there's not a damn thing we can do about it now, okay?

question: You said something to him, didn't you?
You told him about me?
You did, didn't you?
You bastard.
answer: Beth, I didn't. Hold it together. Alright?

question: Yeah, okay. Sure, Norman.

Of course he did. He's been isloated for 400 years. He wants someone to talk to. Look, you put a human being in isolation for four days, they can become neurotic, sometimes psychotic. We're talking about 400 years here. An alien that shows emotional responses. I think we need to address him, before he reacts further.
Yes, I do. Whatever's out there, I think is his response to us refusing to talk to him earlier.
answer: Bullshit. What's out there isn't alien. It's an animal.

question: Maybe so. But I think we need to ask Jerry about it.
answer: No. I think we should shut down the communication lines inside the habitat. He might be listening now.

question: It looked like a tentacle. Of a squid.
answer: A squid? The size of a whale? I don't think so. Target acquired. Sixty yards.

question: What if it attacks?
What do we use for defense?
answer: We're a habitat. Not a castle. The only defense we have is High Voltage.

question: High Voltage?
answer: It sends 200 volts throughout the cylinder surface. But we've never used it underwater before. Forty yards.

question: But you've tested it?
answer: Sure. Each time it started fires inside the habitat. Thirty yards.

question: What are you saying -- we can't stop what's out there?
answer: What the hell? It shut us down.

question: Ted, go into the control room. Listen for my instructions.
Why can't I -- ? What the hell is going on here?
Do it now!
Now!
Pull it, damn it!
Norman Johnson.
answer: Does this mean what I think it means?

question: It's over, sir, The storm has cleared.
They're topside. We're ready to take you home, sir.
The others, sir?
They're in the sub, sir. Waiting.
answer: That whole time -- I couldn't stop thinking of what Harry was saying earlier...

question: What was that, sir?
answer: About the time paradox. How we were all going to die -- that there was no way we would make it out of here alive --

question: Where are you going in such a hurry?
answer: I have to reset the sub.

question: Forget the sub.
It's not worth the risk.
answer: It's also our only way out of here! It holds three people. And there's only three of us left now.

question: You, me and Harry?
answer: You, me and Harry. He's asleep.

question: Wake him, then. Let's go. Get outta --
answer: We can't. The storm. The waves would toss us around worse than we got down here. And we have four days of decompression when we get up top.

question: Four days?
answer: Get the helium out of our bloodstream. We go to the surface now, we'd pop like a soda bottle. Maybe you should go. To the sub.

question: Why should I go?
answer: You should know how it works. Just in case.

question: In case you die, too?
answer: I don't trust Harry to do it.

question: I would. But my suit --
You fixed my suit?
But I don't know how --
answer: You press a button, Norman. It's not brain surgery. Here, go ahead. You only have 15 minutes to reset it. Go on, Norman... ... I'll watch the sensors for you.

question: You're clear, Norman. The sub's a 100 feet in front of you. You see it?
answer: I can't see anything. How does it look? Still clear?

question: Still clear. What's the matter?
Yes, Norman. I did. You're just nervous.
answer: My air isn't... I'm coming back.

question: You can't. Counter's at 10 minutes. You don't have time.
Still clear.
answer: I'm in. Hello? Beth? Beth? Hello? Beth! Beth! There's something -- ! Beth! Shit! Beth? Can you hear me?

question: Beth? Beth? Shit.
Harry?
I can't breathe... Am I... clear?
answer: You're clear. You see the airlock? Norman!

question: Thank you. My suit -- Beth said she fixed it --
What do you mean? She's not here?
answer: When I woke up, nobody was here.

question: She was supposed to be watching the sensor for me.
Beth left?
answer: I thought she was with you.

question: ... what do you mean? I'm in the ship.
answer: What are you doing in the ship? Beth?

question: Getting food. We were out of food. what's wrong? You sound mad.
answer: Yeah, well, I get that way when I'm facing death and someone deserts me.

question: Deserts you? Harry said he'd take over for me.
When he woke up, he said we were out of food. He told me to get some from the ship.
Yes you did. Norman, I wouldn't leave you out there. You know that.
answer: We never even had a conversation, Norman.

question: Harry? That's bullshit. We stood right there --
She's cracking, Norman.
answer: You didn't say that about the food?

question: I was just in the cafeteria, there's plenty of food in there. Take a look for yourself.
What's Harry doing with your suit in there?
Fixing it? But I fixed -- Where'd you get all that?
The refridgerator.
answer: It's a pretty common place to look for food when you don't think you have any.

question: That wasn't in there before.
answer: We must've had it delivered then.

question: Wait a second --
None of this was here before.
answer: Did you look? It was on the top shelf.

question: No, it wasn't. I swear none of this was here. None of it. You think he hid it? Earlier. He must've hid it.
You don't believe me.
answer: All I know is I opened that refridgerator --

question: Damn it, Norman. I swear. I had a whole conversation with the man when he woke up.
answer: This being after you so carefully fixed my suit.

question: You think it's me? You think I'm saying there was a conversation when there wasn't?
answer: I don't know, Beth. I wasn't there.

question: What is it, Norman? Norman? Norman?
What?
answer: Page 87. "I could never read that far." "Our fisherman frequently see some that are more than four feet long. Some skeletons of squids...

question: Squids?
answer: "... according to calculations of some naturalists, one of these animals, only six feet long, would have tentacles 27 feet long. That would make a formidable monster."

question: After the attack, a Navy guy woke me up -- I don't know -- I thought he was an illusion. But I checked the tape, and Jerry said he manifested him.
Created. Brought to life. I don't know. But at the end, Jerry said, "Stop calling me Jerry". And -- He translated it wrong.

Remember when we first spoke to Jerry, Barnes kept asking for Jerry's real name? But Harry never would? He didn't because he was afraid the screen would say "Harry", instead of Jerry. We weren't talking to an alien intelligence when we talked to Jerry, we were talking to Harry... or a part of Harry.
answer: What do you mean, a part of Harry?

question: When did the messages start? The animals outside start showing up? After Harry came out of the sphere.
He acquired some sort of power. A power to manifest things.
I don't know.
answer: How can the sphere do that?

question: I don't know, Beth. I'm not the fucking alien that built the thing. But it can. When Harry came out of the sphere, he mumbled something about page 87. How he would never read that far -- he was too scared to. Then you found the book, remember in your lab. Then in the cafeteria -- and page 87 talks about a giant squid...
answer: Which I told Barnes was attacking --

question: It's his fear. The squid. He's manifesting his fears. Making them real.
answer: But why is he doing it?

question: He must not realize he is. Like the Navy crewman -- Harry was sleeping then. He must've manifested his dream.
answer: His dream? You can't control your dreams. And you can't control your fears, can you?

question: No. I mean, we've always believed we can think anything we want without consequences. You ever read the Bible? It talks about our sinful nature, you know? I mean, we can think, and believe, and desire whatever we want, but there's a part of us -- a shadow side, as Jung called it -- that can't be controlled. It's evil. It's inside us. It's what we are.
answer: And that's the part of Harry that's being manifested.

question: Why would Harry go back to using a code?
Jerry. Right. I said Jerry, didn't I?
answer: That's a hell of a mistake to make, Beth.

question: I'm sorry. Slip of the tongue.
answer: Yeah, I don't know how you could make that confusion. Wisconsin's your answer.

question: Yeah, I don't know how you could make that confusion. Wisconsin's your answer.
Navy transmission. They're sent from Wisconsin.
Don't have to. Watch. It'll do it for you.
answer: The cavalry is on it's way.

question: Just in time, too.
What?
Our habitat, I mean. This place can't handle another attack.
answer: Another attack? Why are you looking at me like that?

question: Like what? I'm not --
No I'm not. I'm not star--
answer: Yes you are... Did I miss something? You two seemed to patch things up awfully fast.

question: Yes you are... Did I miss something? You two seemed to patch things up awfully fast.
answer: We just figured, you know, the three of us -- we need to... work together through this.

question: The three of us.
Diphenyl parlene.
Ephedrine hydrochloride.
Valdomet.
Sintag.
Does it cause drowsiness? That's all we need. To get him unconscious -- put him under.
Tarazine?
Bingo.
answer: "... and may also cause bizarre halucinations".

question: Riordan?
Damn it! Chloramphenicol?
Parasolutrine?
P-a-r-a-s-o...
What's that?
It's like a sleeping pill?
answer: "... used as an anesthetic if given in combination with paracin trichloride... "

question: Here we go. "20 cc's of parasolutrine in combination with 6 cc's of paracin given IV produces deep sleep suitable for emergency surgical procedures... no cardiac side effects ... REM activity is surpressed... "
Three to six hours.
What? Wait -- isn't that dangerous?
answer: How fast does it take effect?

question: Doesn't say.
answer: What if it takes 20 minutes, Norman? What if it takes an hour? And he can fight it off? We can't afford that.

question: What is that? What are you doing? What do you want to do -- kill him?
Beth --
answer: To be on the safe side. I mean --

question: You want to kill him?
answer: Look, it's either him or us, Norman. Another attack, and we go down with this place. You ever given an injection before.

question: Thirty years ago. In residency. I passed out. You?
answer: Only lab rats. Here. Give him the whole thing. Hurry, before he wakes up.

question: What is it?
answer: You know what it is, Harry. It's the squid! Stop it!

question: Stop what? What are you -- ?
answer: You know damn well what. You're doing it!

question: I'm sorry.
Not believing you.
answer: You're not sorry. You're scared. You're a psychologist, Norman. You pride yourself on knowing when someone's lying to you, not telling you the truth. And now you're scared ... because you're not sure you can tell anymore.

question: What is it, Norman?
In the sub. Resetting the timer. Why?
What do you mean, different?
answer: The grooves around the door -- they've shifted. And the pattern -- the fluids -- they look darker now.

question: How's Harry?
Ouch.
answer: What time is it, Norman? Do you know the time? I have to know the time of day, Norman. Do you know?

question: Your watch.
answer: What was that? I couldn't hear you.

question: Your watch.
answer: Oh yes, my watch. I almost forgot. Splendid.

question: Isotonic glucose supplement. Go ahead, drink it. What's wrong, Norman?
Are you? It's getting cold.
answer: You think I'd really drink that?

question: You don't think I put something in it, do you?
answer: You put explosives around the habitat, I can't imagine what you'd put in a drink.

question: I did do that, didn't I?
answer: How do you feel about snakes?

question: Snakes? What do you mean, exactly?
Am I afraid of them? Not during the day. Sea snakes are diurnal. When the sun's out, they don't bite. Fortunately for you, I had on my watch. This is quite good.
answer: What are they doing down here? In the bathroom? Suddenly appearing.

question: You tell me.
Don't you?
If I was, then I would've had to have gone in the sphere, wouldn't I?
What's the phrase -- "keeping up with the Joneses"?
answer: Why did you go in the sphere, Beth?

question: Same reason I put explosives around the habitat. For defense. For the power. To protect myself.
answer: Against what? Harry's unconscious. He's not a threat.

question: No, he isn't.
No, he can't.
answer: Then why, Beth? Why go in? Why put out explosives? Why manifest the snakes?

question: You think I manifested the snakes?
Yes, someone did. But it wasn't me, Norman. It was you. You manifested the snakes.
C'mon -- what?

Am I lying? Are you sure? Are you absolutely sure I'm lying? Then explain to me about the jellyfish. Earlier. Why did we see jellyfish? Harry doesn't fear jellyfish. You do. They're your fear, aren't they?
And the snakes? You want to know about the snakes? You saw one outside earlier, didn't you? When you thought I had deserted you -- you were terrified.
answer: That's when you went in the sphere.

question: One lonely, terrifying sea snake.

Did I? Or was that you? When you were hiding in the bathroom -- all conspiratorially like you were -- you became frightened, didn't you? Terrified. Like you were with the snake earlier -- and suddenly you have snakes slithering all over the floor. You did that, Norman.
Am I? Or am I making so much sense that you're going insane?
answer: I never went in that sphere.

question: You don't remember you did. But I'm sure you remember running like some fucking hero to get Harry, don't you? You remember that.

You remember before you picked him up -- when you looked up at the sphere, you remember that -- when the sphere opened? That's right. But you can't remember going inside, can you? No, of course not. Harry couldn't either, could he? "Like everything's on the tip of my tongue", he said.
Is it?
answer: Beth, the message said Harry. "My name is Harry". My name isn't Harry.

question: No, it isn't. Your name is Norman. But your younger brother -- what was his name? The one who was stung when you were younger. The one that died. The one you couldn't save. What was his name? "Mommy, we're going out to the ocean -- to go swimming." "But I don't want to go swimming, Norman. I'm scared." "C'mon, Harry, it'll be fine, it'll be fun." You heartless fuck. That's why you're so scared of the water, isn't it?

When you were in that sub -- and that squid was attacking you -- are you sure it was the squid that was attacking? Do you know? "I can't get Beth on the radio. I'm in this tiny sub on the bottom of the fucking ocean. All alone. Surrounded by all this water." Was it really the squid that was attacking you, Norman -- or was it something else -- one of your fears? You never really saw what it was, did you? I'm not scaring you, am I Norman? I hope I'm not frightening you. The last thing I want to do is frighten you. You feel okay, don't you?
answer: It's not me, Beth. I swear. It can't be.

question: "It's not me, Beth. It's not me. It can't be. I'm not doing anything." Just like Harry said before I stabbed him with the needle.
But I have to, Norman.
Promise what, Norman? Tell me!
You think I'd belive you? Believe anything you might say now? After you lied to me about telling Barnes about my past. About my problems. My problems. Not yours. Not his. Mine.
It's either this... or I kill you.
It's your choice. Because it's not safe for you to be awake. To be walking around. To be thinking about things.
answer: It's not safe for you to be either.

question: You think I care? You think I care if I die? Would I put explosives around the habitat -- set on vibration sensors -- that can trigger automatically, if I cared about myself? Would I? I've tried twice before, Norman, why wouldn't I try a third time? I'm not thinking about myself -- No, Norman, I'm thinking about you. Your safety. Protecting you from your own self. Norman! I'm doing this for you, Norman. Norman. Come here, Norman. Norman -- This is what I'm talking about, Norman. Don't you see? It's in you. This vindictiveness. This rage.
answer: Get away from the door, Beth.

question: Of course you're going to deny it. You want to blame someone else. You want to blame Beth. Because you hate Beth.
I'm not fucking with you, Norman. You've fucked yourself.
answer: Turn off the water, Beth. Beth!

question: You're frightened, aren't you, Norman?
answer: Where is it coming from, Beth?

question: Don't you know?
Stop what? Don't blame me. It's not me.
From you, Norman. From your mind. You're doing it. There's no ventalation in the room, Norman. The pressure's going to kill you.
Beth?
I can't do that.
answer: You can't stop it, Norman. You can't fight me.

question: I know. You're too strong, Beth.
answer: Oh please, don't shrink me, Norman. Not now. Don't tell me about me. I already know too much.

question: Beth -- gimme the gun.
answer: Oh, sure. Here. Anything else, Beth can get you? Some more chicken, perhaps. Let Beth check the fridge.

question: C'mon --
C'mon, Beth.
answer: It's over, Norman. Go on, get outta here. What is that? What are you doing?

question: What?
Hear what?
Beth --
Shit. Harry! I'm gonna have to lift her up to you.
answer: Alright. Hurry. I can't reach her.

question: Hold on.
I'm trying. Shit. Here -- catch her.
Hold on.
I heard! I heard!
Shut up and catch.
answer: I got her. I got her.

question: Alright, here, I'll... wait, you -- just give her to me.
Take her, come on. Just --
I'm trying to keep balance with --
Just pull her -- down like inside -- Harry, work with me here!
answer: Her legs are in the way.

question: You got her? Get her out of the seat, I need room to sit. Harry?
The shock wave's gonna crush us, Norman.
How's that working out, by the way?
answer: Good. Thank you. Now that I have it on. Why are you laughing? You don't even know what that means.

question: Won't make any difference. The tapes document everything.
We all kill ourselves? Bad joke. Sorry, Beth.
answer: The power allows us to manifest our fears, right? What if we feared the power to go away?

question: You mean forget?
answer: It would erase all our knowledge of it. All of our power.

question: It would erase all our knowledge of it. All of our power.
Yes. And I think we already know it will.
